item.title: LIPS History
item.description: This is the first article on LIPS blog. In this article I will write about the history of LIPS
item.content:encoded:
This is the first article on LIPS blog. In this article I will write about the history of LIPS Scheme interpreter.

What is Scheme?​

Scheme is a dialect of the Lisp. The second oldest programming language still in use (after Fortran). Lisp and Scheme have specific syntax with prefix notation and where everything is a list. It's also Homoiconic, which means that code and data have the same represantion. This allows to write lisp (and Scheme) programs that modify the code like it was data.

What is LIPS?​

LIPS name is a recursive ancronym which stands for "LIPS Is Pretty Simple". LIPS Scheme is implementation of Scheme programming language in JavaScript. It adds a lot of stuff on top of Scheme to make it more powerful and easier to interact with JavaScript.

History of LIPS​

It all started in February of 2018. I've written the first version of Lisp interpreter. You can still see the code on CodePen. Then I moved the devlopment to GitHub and created a name LIPS. The first release (version 0.2.0) is marked as Mar 2018.

At the begining it was Lisp based on Scheme, but at one point after version 0.20.1 dated as Jul 1, 2020. I've starting adding features on devel branch and decided that I want full Scheme implementation. But it turns out that there are way to many breaking changes to release next version. So I decided that I will release it as beta-1.0. Since then LIPS keeps introducing new Beta version. You can see the latest release on GitHub.

Future of LIPS​

For the future plans I want in version 1.0 are implementation of continutations and TCO. To see the progress you can check 1.0 Milestone on GitHub.
